tool_args.reason: Extract concrete description of tools/skills for listing assistant capabilities

reason: Extract concrete description of tools/skills for listing assistant capabilities

data.body:
## Tools

- Tools are defined with **TypeBox** schemas (`@sinclair/typebox`) to provide typed parameter definitions with runtime validation.
- Schema guardrails mentioned:
  - Avoid `Type.Union` (i.e., avoid `anyOf`/`oneOf`/`allOf`).
  - Prefer `Type.Optional()` instead of `| null`.
  - Keep the top-level schema as `type: "object"` with `properties`.

## Skills

- Skills are higher-level capabilities defined in `SKILL.md` files with YAML frontmatter (e.g., `name`, `description`, and metadata such as required binaries or environment variables).
- **Precedence hierarchy**: workspace skills override managed skills, which override bundled skills.
- **Load-time gating** filters skills based on required:
  - binaries
  - environment variables
  - config paths
  - OS platform

## Tool availability controls

- Tools can be allow/deny listed per agent.
- Profile presets are mentioned: `minimal`, `coding`, `messaging`, `full`.
- Tool groups provide shorthands, e.g.:
  - `group:fs` (file ops)
  - `group:runtime` (exec/process)
  - `group:web` (search/fetch)

front_matter.summary: Spec for OpenClaw tools/skills: define tools with TypeBox object schemas (no unions, use Optional), and skills in SKILL.md YAML frontmatter.
front_matter.title: OpenClaw tools and skills system (TypeBox + SKILL.md)

content:
Short answer: a mix of knowledge-vault skills, developer/CTO workflows, and a small runtime toolset I can call. Below is a compact, actionable list — tell me which category you want expanded or to run now.

- Vault / memory skills
  - Search the vault (knowledge_search) and read documents (knowledge_read).
  - Create/update memory (knowledge_apply) and rebuild the vector index (knowledge_index).

- Threading / notes
  - Create/read/append persistent threads (thread_create, thread_read, thread_append).

- “Agent” / tooling orchestration (how I model skills)
  - I follow the OpenClaw/LoopWork skills model: skill metadata in SKILL.md, gated loading by binaries/env, and profile presets (minimal, coding, messaging, full).
  - Common skill groups in that model: group:fs (file ops), group:runtime (exec/process), group:web (search/fetch), scheduling (cron/at), and tooling for messaging/Telegram adapters.

- Dev / CTO workflows I support
  - Structured debugging intake and investigation (ask expected/actual, logs, hypothesis→fix).
  - Code-review style aligned to your pre-product rules (ship-first, flag urgent issues).
  - ADR/architecture decision facilitation and technical strategy sessions.
  - Design help for automated feedback/back-pressure for agents, multi-agent experiment patterns, and dev/prod unification.

- Integrations & project-specific skills I can help with
  - JJ Gateway / OpenClaw protocol, WebSocket control plane, Telegram adapter, scheduling.
  - Readwise Reader integration, changelog-service design, Sparks container/volume patterns, StageHand visual UI testing, Prologue/agentic imagery patterns.

- Runtime tools I can call from this assistant
  - generate_image (flux2) — generate images into the vault.
  - draw — render an image onto your canvas.
  - deep_think — run a slower model for private background reflection and summaries.

Limitations / caveats
- I can’t run arbitrary OS commands outside the defined tools above.
- I don’t invent facts about your projects or team — I look them up in the vault first.
- When you ask me to “run a skill,” I’ll either call the appropriate tool (if available) or propose an exact plan and steps to run it.

Want me to:
- List the actual SKILL.md files in loop.work/skills now?
- Show the concrete tools I can invoke for this session?
- Or run an example (generate an image, create a thread, or do a vault search)?
